sequence.notes: Epoxidation of the internal alkene of β-citronellene with m-CPBA, leaving the terminal alkene untouched. The chiral center's stereochemistry is retained.

Acid-catalyzed epoxide ring opening with water to form a 1,2-diol. The stereochemistry at the existing chiral center (C3 from the alkene) is retained as (S). A new chiral center is formed at C7 (next to the gem-dimethyl group) with (R) configuration, where the hydroxyl group is shown as a dashed bond.
Periodate cleavage of a 1,2-diol to an aldehyde, with a tertiary alcohol being cleaved off (likely as acetone). The alkene and the chiral center are preserved.
Oxidation of an aldehyde to a carboxylic acid.

sequence.reaction_type: Mixed Anhydride Formation / Carboxylic Acid Activation
sequence.notes: Formation of a mixed anhydride by reacting a carboxylic acid with pivaloyl chloride and triethylamine.
Acylation of a chiral oxazolidinone auxiliary with an acyl pivalic anhydride.
An Evan's asymmetric aldol reaction where an acyl oxazolidinone adds to a chiral protected aldehyde, forming a new C-C bond and multiple stereocenters.

substeps.notes: Methylation of two secondary alcohol groups on a protected D-mannitol derivative.
Hydrogenolysis of two benzylidene acetals to yield an open-chain hexitol derivative with two methoxy groups.
Selective protection of primary alcohols as TBDPS ethers.
Oxidative cleavage of a polyol (1,2-diol equivalent) using lead tetraacetate (Pb(OAc)4) to form an aldehyde.

sequence.notes: Reduction of a N-acyl oxazolidinone to a primary alcohol, cleaving the chiral auxiliary.
Selective tosylation of a primary alcohol to form a tosylate.
Reductive removal of a primary tosylate to form a methyl group using lithium triethylborohydride, retaining existing stereochemistry.
Deprotection of TBDPS ether to a primary alcohol.
Formation of a 1,3-dioxane cyclic acetal from a 1,3-diol and an acetal (4-methoxyphenyl dimethoxymethane) catalyzed by camphorsulfonic acid.
Reductive opening of a cyclic acetal (1,3-dioxane) using DIBAL-H, forming a p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) ether and a primary alcohol.
Primary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde using Swern oxidation conditions.
Nozaki-Takai-Hiyama-Kishi coupling of an aldehyde with a vinyl iodide.

substeps.notes: Asymmetric functionalization of trans-2-butene via organoboron reagents. The product is a diisopinocampheyl-(trans-but-2-en-1-yl)borane.
Asymmetric carbon-carbon bond formation via crotylboration of an aldehyde, followed by oxidative workup.
PMB-etherification of a secondary alcohol. The original hydroxyl group is protected as a PMB ether while the TBS group remains intact. Stereochemistry at both chiral centers is retained.
Ozonolysis of a terminal alkene to form an aldehyde, with reductive workup (Me2S). Stereochemistry of existing chiral centers is preserved.
Aldehyde converted to gem-dibromoalkene. Stereochemistry of chiral centers is retained.
Corey-Fuchs reaction of gem-dibromoalkene to form an alkyne, followed by methylation.
Alkyne converted to Z-vinyl iodide with retention of stereochemistry at chiral centers.

sequence.notes: Secondary alcohol is protected as a triisopropylsilyl (TIPS) ether.
Deprotection of a tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether to a primary alcohol using HF·pyridine.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde.
Asymmetric aldol reaction of an aldehyde with a complex Evans auxiliary to form a beta-hydroxy alpha-methyl ketone.

substeps.notes: Asymmetric reduction of an α-bromo-α,β-unsaturated ketone to a chiral allylic alcohol using the Corey-Bakshi-Shibata (CBS) reagent.
Debromination of a vinyl bromide using lithium metal and t-butanol as a proton source, retaining the stereochemistry of the hydroxyl group.
Stereoselective epoxidation of an allylic alcohol, forming the epoxide syn to the existing hydroxyl group.
O-benzylation of secondary alcohol. All stereochemistry retained from reactant to product.
Acid-catalyzed methanolysis of an epoxide, yielding a trans-1,2-hydroxy ether and retaining the benzyloxy group's stereochemistry.
Hydroxyl group converted to tert-butyldimethylsilyl ether (OTBS).
Hydrogenolysis of a benzyl ether to yield an alcohol, leaving other protected groups (OMe, OTBS) intact.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone using Swern conditions.
Formation of a silyl enol ether from a cyclohexanone, retaining the relative stereochemistry of the existing chiral centers.
Palladium-catalyzed oxidation of a silyl enol ether to an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone, with retention of stereochemistry at the methoxy and TBS-protected alcohol carbons.
Diastereoselective reduction of an alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone to an allylic alcohol, forming the anti-alcohol with respect to the methoxy group.
Eschenmoser-Claisen rearrangement converting an allyl alcohol to an N,N-dimethylamide, involving a silyl protecting group and a methoxy group. Stereochemistry is maintained/controlled.
Amide reduced to primary alcohol using Lithium triethylborohydride (Super Hydride). Stereochemistry at the chiral centers on the cyclohexene ring is retained.
Hydrogenation of the internal alkene in the cyclohexene ring, forming a saturated cyclohexane. Stereochemistry of existing chiral centers is retained.
Mitsunobu-like substitution of a primary alcohol with 2-nitrophenyl selenocyanate.
Grieco elimination, oxidation of selenide to selenoxide, followed by syn-elimination.
Ozonolysis of a vinyl group to an aldehyde.
Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons olefination of an aldehyde to form an alpha,beta-unsaturated amide.
Reductive saturation of the alpha,beta-unsaturated carbonyl system using triethylsilane and Wilkinson's catalyst, while preserving stereochemistry elsewhere.
Cleavage of the TBS (tert-butyldimethylsilyl) protecting group on a secondary alcohol to yield a free hydroxyl group.
Protection of a secondary alcohol with tert-butyldiphenylsilyl chloride (TBDPSCl). The reaction involves the conversion of a hydroxyl group (-OH) to a tert-butyldiphenylsilyl ether (-OTBDPS).

sequence.notes: Amide reduction with LiBH4, removal of chiral oxazolidinone auxiliary, forming a primary alcohol.
Primary alcohol is selectively tosylated.
Reductive cleavage of a primary tosylate to a methyl group.
Esterification of a secondary alcohol with N-Boc-pipecolic acid.
Terminal alkene is converted to a syn-1,2-diol using OsO4/NMO. The internal trans-alkene remains unchanged.
Oxidative cleavage of a vicinal diol (1,2-diol) to an aldehyde using lead tetraacetate.
Aldehyde converted to (E)-vinyl iodide via Takai olefination. All protecting groups and stereocenters on the main chain and cyclohexane are preserved.
Oxidative deprotection of two p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) ethers to hydroxyls and a tert-butoxycarbonyl (Boc)-protected amine to a free amine.
Two secondary hydroxyl groups are converted to triethylsilyl (TES) ethers.
Macrolactamization and macrolactone formation via amide and ester bonds, using DIC/HoBt coupling to form Rapamycin intermediate.

substeps.notes: Formation of a 1,3-dioxolane (isopropylidene acetal) from the diol side chain of L-ascorbic acid.

Oxidative cleavage of an enediol-lactone (ascorbic acid derivative) to a carboxylic acid with an adjacent alpha-hydroxy group, preserving the acetonide. Likely a modified Heyns-Ruff degradation or similar oxidative ring opening.
Esterification of a carboxylic acid to an ethyl ester using ethyl iodide. The stereochemistry of both chiral centers is retained.
The secondary alcohol is converted into a p-toluenesulfonate (tosylate) group with retention of stereochemistry.
Chloride replaces tosylate. Racemization occurs at the carbon bearing the tosylate/chloride group, as indicated by the wavy bond.
Reductive removal of a chlorine atom alpha to an ester, maintaining the stereochemistry of the acetonide-protected diol.
Ester hydrolysis of ethyl ester to carboxylic acid, acetonide protecting group remains intact.
Formation of a Weinreb amide from a carboxylic acid using DCC as a coupling agent and N,O-dimethylhydroxylamine hydrochloride.

substeps.reaction_type: Weinreb Amide Addition / Vinyl Lithium Addition
substeps.notes: Addition of an in-situ generated vinyl lithium reagent to a Weinreb amide, forming an (E)-alpha,beta-unsaturated ketone.
Stereoselective reduction of a ketone to an alcohol using lithium aluminum hydride, while preserving an acetonide and a trimethylsilyl alkene.
Methylation of a secondary alcohol to a methyl ether.
Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of an acetonide protecting group to reveal a 1,2-diol.
Primary alcohol is converted to a mesylate. Other stereocenters and alkene geometry are preserved.

Intramolecular cyclization to form an epoxide from a vicinal alcohol and mesylate. The reaction proceeds via SN2, which typically involves retention of configuration at the attacking carbon (C6 in this case, where the hydroxyl group is located) and inversion at the attacked carbon (C7, where the mesylate leaves). Since C7 is a primary carbon, it's not a chiral center. The stereochemistry at C6 should be retained. The original product SMILES had an inverted stereochemistry at C6, which has been corrected.
Nucleophilic ring opening of an epoxide by an organocuprate derived from an alkyl iodide and 2-thienylCu(CN)Li, followed by protonation to form an alcohol.
A secondary alcohol is protected as a triisopropylsilyl (TIPS) ether using i-Pr3SiOTf and 2,6-lutidine.
Iododesilylation of a vinylsilane to form a vinyl iodide with retention of configuration.
Deprotection of PMB ether to primary alcohol using DDQ. Stereochemistry and alkene geometry corrected, and common groups abbreviated.
Oxidation of primary alcohol to aldehyde.
Stereoselective Aldol addition of an alpha-hydroxy ester enolate to an aldehyde, forming two new hydroxyl groups with mixed stereochemistry.
Saponification of methyl ester to carboxylic acid.

sequence.notes: Swern oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone, forming a 1,2-diketone system adjacent to an ester.
Hydrolysis of TES and one TIPS silyl ether protecting group to form hydroxyl groups. The other TIPS and TBDPS groups are retained.
Oxidation of two secondary alcohols to ketones.
Deprotection of silyl ethers (TIPS, TBDPS) and intramolecular cyclization involving two vinyl iodides and an alkene to form a 2-hydroxy-2,5-dihydrofuran ring. This transformation occurs over 4 steps.

Intramolecular double Stille coupling of a di-iodinated rapamycin derivative with a dienyl stannane to form Rapamycin. The reactant and product SMILES provided by extraction are highly problematic with deep structural inaccuracies (e.g., C(=O)C(=O) instead of amide/lactone system) and repeated fragments, which cannot be fully corrected without re-generating the SMILES from scratch using a cheminformatics tool. The provided SMILES for the reagent was entirely junk and has been replaced with the correct structure.
